intro: Ruellia dubia, commonly known as the ghost flower, is a flowering plant native to the Caribbean and parts of Central America. It is a member of the Acanthaceae family and is characterized by its striking, pale blue to violet flowers. The plant typically grows as an annual or perennial herb, often reaching heights of up to 1 meter. Its leaves are opposite, ovate, and covered in fine hairs, while its flowers are clustered in whorls at the ends of the stems. Ruellia dubia is known for its ability to thrive in a variety of soil types and is often found in disturbed or open habitats.
